title: Banking Basics in Canada
description: Understand how to choose your first bank and the difference between accounts.

content.title: Chequing vs. Savings
content.text: A chequing account is for daily spending (paying bills, groceries). A savings account is for keeping money long-term and earns a small amount of interest. Most Canadian banks offer 'Newcomer Packages' with no monthly fees for the first year.

content.title: Avoid ATM Fees
content.text: Using an ATM that doesn't belong to your bank can cost you $2 to $5 per withdrawal. Stick to your own bank's machines to keep your money in your pocket.

quiz.question: Which account should you use for your daily grocery shopping?
quiz.explanation: Chequing accounts are designed for frequent daily transactions, while savings accounts are for building a safety net.

quiz.question: True or False: Most major Canadian banks offer free banking for newcomers for a limited time.
quiz.explanation: True! Most of the 'Big Five' banks have newcomer programs that waive monthly fees for 6 to 12 months.
